paper_abstract: For n = 2(k), we know that the size of a smallest AND/OR/NOT formula computing the Boolean function Parity(x(1), ..., x(n)) = Odd(x(1), ... , x(n)) is exactly n(2): For any n, it is at least n(2) by the classical Khrapchenko bound, and for n = 2(k) we easily obtain a formula of size n(2) by writing and recursively expanding Odd(x(1), ..., x(n)) = [Odd(x(1), ..., x(n/2)) boolean AND Even(x(n/2+1), ..., x(n))] boolean OR [Even(x(1), ..., x(n/2)) boolean AND Odd(x(n/2+1), ... , x(n))]. We show that for n = 2(k) the formula obtained above is an essentially unique one that computes Parity(x(1), ... , x(n)) with size n(2). In the equivalent framework of the Karchmer-Wigderson communication game, our result means that an optimal protocol for the parity of 2(k) variables is essentially unique. (C) 2010 Elsevier B.V. paper_title: Smallest formulas for the parity of 2(k) variables are essentially unique
